input:
30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)

Covers Software 1.0 (Analysis & Data Pipelines), Software 2.0 (ML), Software 3.0 (Prompt Engineering, RAG, AI Agents, Fine-tuning)
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose and Target Audience
- Purpose: Educate and promote a free guide; share practical project ideas across the AI spectrum (Software 1.0 to 3.0).
- Target Audience: Aspiring AI engineers, technical creators, and anyone interested in hands-on AI projects (beginners to advanced).

Step 2: Wireframe
[Hook: Calls out the scope/utility of building 30 AI projects in 1 weekend, emphasizes breadth—from classic to cutting-edge, and teases a free guide.]
[Meat: Short intro explaining the three "layers" (Software 1.0, 2.0, 3.0), then quick list/summary of project types included for each. Emphasize practicality—no fluff.]
[Link to free guide.]
[CTA: Ask for project ideas readers would add to the list.]

Step 3: Meat
- There are three major “layers” for AI builders today:
  • Software 1.0: Data analysis, cleaning, pipelines—use code to prepare and process info
  • Software 2.0: Build actual ML and predictive systems (think classic models and neural nets)
  • Software 3.0: The new frontier—build LLM-powered tools, automate with agents, do RAG, tune models yourself
- The free guide has 30 hands-on project ideas, from scraping and visualizing real-world data, to training simple classifiers, to prototyping RAG chatbots and automations with OpenAI or open-source models.
- Every project is scoped for a weekend (or less) and has practical learning value. 

Step 4: CTA
👉 What’s one AI project idea you’d add?

Step 5: Hooks (brainstormed directions)
A. [User’s own phrasing] "30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)"
B. [Beginner-to-expert clarity] “Most lists focus on one kind of project. Here’s 30 from analysis to fine-tuning.”
C. [Problem/solution] “Confused by which AI projects to build? I organized 30 you can actually finish—and learn from.”
D. [Results] “You can build a real AI portfolio in a month—here’s 30 weekend-sized projects to pick from.”
E. [Trend/urgency] “GenAI is just a part of modern AI building—don’t skip the fundamentals. Here’s projects from 1.0 through 3.0.”

Step 5B: Notes on directions
A. User phrasing is clear, direct, and covers volume
B. Position as full-spectrum; good for leveling-up.
C. Solution/problem—good for explaining pain point
D. Portfolio approach is aspirational, but may overpromise for some
E. Breadth/learning angle—reinforces important technical depth

Step 5C: Choose strongest direction and write hook
Direction A (User’s own phrasing) has the clearest value/hook and literal match—“30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)”

Step 6: Full Draft
30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)

If you want to level up as an AI builder, you need hands-on projects—and not just with the latest GenAI tools.

I put together a list of 30 project ideas you can actually finish in a weekend.

They cover the full stack:
• Software 1.0 – Data pipelines, scraping, and analysis projects
• Software 2.0 – Classic ML and deep learning models
• Software 3.0 – Prompt engineering, RAG, agent automation, and fine-tuning

You’ll find ideas for:
- Scraping and visualizing real-world data
- Building your first classifier
- Experimenting with LLMs and setting up your own AI chatbot

Every project is practical, with no filler or hype—and every one builds real skills.

Grab the free guide here: [link]

👉 What’s one AI project idea you’d add to this list?

Step 7: Review
- No business clichés or motivational language
- Factual, practical, includes technical details
- Hoover white space and bulleted lists
- Clear, direct, action-oriented CTA
- Hook matches user language

Step 8: Write the final post
final_post:
